question: Before April 1, 2025, will Donald Trump expresses his desire to run for a third term in 2028?
description: [Trump jokes about running for a third term in speech to House Republicans](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/13/us/politics/congress-resolution-22nd-amendment-loophole.html?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email)
fine_print: For purposes of this question, Trump's [statement in November 2024](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/13/us/politics/congress-resolution-22nd-amendment-loophole.html?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email) " will not count, because he did not say he wanted to run again. His statement was, “I suspect I won’t be running again unless you say, ‘He’s so good we’ve got to figure something else out,’” In order to count, Trump must publicly express his desire to run, not speculate about whether he can do so.
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Trump's Jokes About a Third Term Raise Concerns**
Donald Trump has started his second term as President of the United States, but has already begun joking about the possibility of serving a third term. 'Can I run again?', Trump joked during a Republican retreat in Florida last month. Trump has made similar comments in the past, suggesting that he might want to stay in office beyond his second term. 'I guess I won't run again unless you say: 'He's so good, we have to think of something else'', Trump said with laughter from lawmakers. Trump has repeatedly stated that this will be his last term, but his comments have raised alarm among his critics, who point to his attempts to overturn his 2020 election loss and his pardoning of rioters who stormed the US Capitol on January 6, 2021. However, Trump has said that he will be 82 years old when his term ends, and seeking another term would clearly violate the Constitution. Some Republicans have argued that the 22nd Amendment, which prohibits a president from being elected more than twice, only applies to consecutive terms, but this interpretation is not supported by the text of the amendment. Others have suggested that Trump could run as vice president and then replace the president if they resign, but this is a complex and unlikely plan. At least one Republican in Congress has proposed a constitutional amendment to allow Trump to seek another term, but it has no chance of passing. Even if Trump tried to run again, a combination of election officials and courts would likely prevent him from appearing on the ballot. Trump's comments about a third term may be a way to maintain his influence in the future, as his time in office is coming to an end. 'He governs as if it's his last presidency, with nothing to lose', said Derek Muller, a professor at Notre Dame Law School. This story was translated from English by an AP editor with the help of a generative AI tool. 
Original language: es
Publish date: February 13, 2025 06:11 AM
Source:[AP NEWS](https://apnews.com/article/trump-tercer-mandato-broma-desafio-c83341ed1e099dc22f75289a70d9de29)

**World News | Trump's Third-term Musings Seem More Tease Than Pledge | LatestLY**
President Donald Trump has been making comments about potentially serving a third term, despite the US Constitution limiting the president to two terms. Trump joked during a House Republican retreat that he might be allowed to run again, and has previously suggested he might want to stick around after his second term. However, his musings have sparked alarm among critics, given his history of trying to overturn the 2020 election and pardoning supporters who violently attacked the US Capitol. Trump has repeatedly said that this will be his last term, but some supporters have proposed a constitutional amendment to allow him to seek another term. Experts say that even if Trump attempted another run, a combination of election officials and courts would ensure that he stayed off the ballot. Trump's comments may be a strategic move to maintain his political clout as a lame duck president.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 13, 2025 06:00 AM
Source:[LatestLY](https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-trumps-third-term-musings-seem-more-tease-than-pledge-6639419.html)

**Trump keeps floating the idea of serving a third term**
President Donald Trump has repeatedly expressed interest in serving a third term as president, despite the notion being unconstitutional. Trump first floated the idea years ago, and has continued to mention it since taking office. Some Republicans, such as Rep. Andy Ogles, have been open to the idea, while Democrats have called on their GOP colleagues to rebuke the president's proposition. Trump cannot constitutionally run for president in 2028, but some have suggested roundabout ways he could serve a third term, including running as vice president and then assuming the presidency. Trump's willingness to stretch the boundaries of his executive power and disregard political norms has led some to take his idea seriously.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 12, 2025 12:14 AM
Source:[MSNBC.com](https://www.msnbc.com/top-stories/latest/trump-third-term-president-constitution-2028-rcna191719)

**Trump's Third Term: A Possibility?**
Donald Trump has hinted at the possibility of running for a third term as President of the United States, despite the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution, which prohibits a president from being elected more than twice. Trump has made several comments suggesting he may run again, including saying 'I suspect I won't run again, unless they do something. Unless they say: 'He's so good, we have to resolve it''. Trump's comments have sparked concerns among Democrats and some Republicans, who fear he may find a way to circumvent the Constitution and run for a third term. Some have suggested that Trump could run for Vice President in 2028 and then assume the presidency if the Vice President resigns or is unable to serve. Others have pointed out that the 22nd Amendment only prohibits a president from being elected more than twice, not from serving as president in some other way. Trump has denied any plans to run for a third term, but his comments have raised questions about his intentions and the possibility of him finding a way to stay in power beyond his current term.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 11, 2025 11:52 PM
Source:[SinEmbargo MX](https://www.sinembargo.mx/4615377/trump-no-para-de-bromear-sobre-reelegirse-otra-vez-y-en-eu-temen-que-si-sea-posible/)

**This is a Genuine Crisis**
The author argues that Donald Trump's ambitions to stay in office beyond 2028 are genuine and pose a threat to American democracy. Trump has talked about a third term at least three times since his inauguration, and his administration's recent actions suggest that they will disregard legal constraints if they want to. The author notes that Trump's supporters, including JD Vance, have laid the groundwork for disregarding legal rulings and have paved the way for a genuine Constitutional crisis. The author believes that Trump will disregard the rulings of a judge and set a new precedent that places all legal power in the hands of the Presidency, making the Constitution irrelevant. The author concludes that it is too late to stop Trump and that the country is at risk of becoming a fascist autocracy.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2025 08:45 PM
Source:[thebanter.substack.com](https://thebanter.substack.com/p/this-is-a-genuine-crisis)

**Donald Trump Leaves JD Vance Embarrassed When Asked If He Will Endorse VP as President in the 2028 Election**
Donald Trump, the President of the United States, has stated that he will not endorse his Vice President, JD Vance, for the 2028 presidential election. In an interview with Fox News, Trump said, 'No,' when asked if he would support Vance, citing that it's 'too early' to make such a decision. Trump's comments have been met with ridicule on social media, with some users calling it 'brutal' and 'honest but still brutal.' Meanwhile, some people believe that Trump 'dodged the question' because he has no intention of leaving office, as he has expressed his desire to run for a third term. However, the 22nd Amendment to the US Constitution prohibits a person from being elected to the office of the President more than twice. A Republican House member, Rep. Andy Ogles, has proposed extending the maximum of two elected terms, but the resolution was cleverly drafted to stop other living presidents from getting elected.

Publish date: February 11, 2025 03:38 PM
Source:[inquisitr.com](https://www.inquisitr.com/heres-the-full-url-version-of-your-title-donald-trump-leaves-jd-vance-embarrassed-when-asked-if-he-will-endorse-vp-as-president-in-2028-election)

**Donald Trump’s Scathing One-Word Answer When Asked if He Views J.D. Vance as His Successor**
Donald Trump, when asked if he sees J.D. Vance as the 2028 Republican nominee, bluntly replied, 'No.' Although Trump praised Vance's capabilities, stating that 'he's doing a fantastic job,' he emphasized that it's 'too early' to endorse him. Trump's comments come as fellow Republican Tennessee Rep. Andy Ogles proposed an amendment to enable Trump to run for a third term in 2028, despite the 22nd Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, which states that 'No person shall be elected to the office of the President more than twice.'

**'You have lot of very capable people': Trump denies endorsing JD Vance for 2028 presidential run as GOP candidate**
US President Donald Trump denied endorsing Vice President JD Vance for the 2028 presidential run, stating it's 'too early' and they are 'just starting'. Trump said Vance is 'very capable' and doing a 'fantastic job', but emphasized that he has not made any endorsement. Trump has previously expressed his desire to run for a third term, despite the 22nd Amendment limiting a president to two terms. A recent survey found 27% of GOP voters want Vance to run for president in 2028, but Vance himself said 'we'll see what happens come 2028' when asked about his potential candidacy.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2025 04:50 AM
Source:[WION](https://www.wionews.com/world/you-have-lot-of-very-capable-people-trump-denies-endorsing-jd-vance-for-2028-presidential-run-as-gop-candidate-8709323)

**Trump Once Again Suggests He Might Try To Run For Third Term In 2028**
Donald Trump has once again suggested that he might attempt a third run at president in 2028, despite the Constitution only allowing two terms in office per candidate. Trump made the hint during a speech at the National Prayer Breakfast event, saying, 'I want to be here with you. And I have been here with you. And I do that despite the fact that they say I can't run again.' Trump has been suggesting a third term since at least 2020 and has received support from some Republicans, including Rep. Andy Ogles (R-Tenn.), who introduced an amendment to allow Trump to run for a third term. However, others, such as Rep. Dan Goldman (D-N.Y.), have criticized Trump's remarks as 'unconstitutional and anti-democratic.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 11:11 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-once-again-suggests-might-230621871.html)

**Why Trump will (probably) run again for president in 2028**
Donald Trump has been hinting at running for a third term as president in 2028, despite the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution limiting a president to two terms. Trump has been dropping subtle hints about his intentions, saying 'we'll go for another four years' and 'it will be the greatest honor of my life to serve not once but twice — or three or four times.' While it's unlikely that the Constitution will be changed to allow Trump to serve more than two terms, he may attempt to run anyway. Trump's supporters have shown a willingness to challenge constitutional precedent, and the president has a history of pushing boundaries. Even if Trump is not eligible to run, it's unclear who would stop him, given the Republican Party's support for him. Trump's biggest hurdle may be ballot access, but it's unlikely that a credible Republican would challenge him. Ultimately, Trump's decision to run for a third term will depend on his own desires and the political landscape at the time.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 05, 2025 06:27 PM
Source:[rollcall.com](https://rollcall.com/2025/02/05/donald-trump-third-term-2028-election/)

**Trump Hints at Running for Third Term**
According to CNN, former US President Donald Trump hinted at running for a third term during a Republican conference dinner in Florida on January 27. Trump stated, 'I've raised a lot of money for the next election, but I'm not 100% sure I can use it for myself.' He also asked House Speaker Mike Johnson, 'I'm not sure if I can run again, Mike? I'd rather not get you involved in this.' This is not the first time Trump has hinted at a potential third term. During a speech in Las Vegas on the previous Sunday, he said, 'It would be the greatest honor to serve not once, but twice or three times,' further fueling speculation about his future political plans.

**Donald Trump jokes about running for third term: 'Am I allowed to run again?'**
US President Donald Trump has joked about running for a third term in 2028, citing uncertainty about his eligibility under current laws. Trump, who is limited to two terms by the 22nd Amendment to the US Constitution, raised the possibility of a third term during a speech to Republican Members of Congress in Miami, Florida. Trump ally Rep. Andy Ogles has introduced a resolution to amend the Constitution, potentially allowing Trump to serve a third term if he wins two non-consecutive elections. However, the amendment would require significant political support to pass and has not made progress in the legislative process. Trump has repeatedly teased the idea of a third term, joking that it would be the 'greatest honour of my life' to serve 'not once, but twice or three times or four times.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: January 28, 2025 06:35 AM
Source:[MoneyControl](https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/world/donald-trump-jokes-about-running-for-third-term-am-i-allowed-to-run-again-12921166.html)

**Trump Uncertain About Running for 2028 Presidential Election**
US President Donald Trump stated that he is not entirely sure if he will be allowed to run for the 2028 presidential election. Trump said, 'I've raised a lot of money for the next campaign and I suppose I won't be able to use it for myself, but I'm not 100% sure.' A Republican congressman, Andy Ogles, has proposed a bill to modify the US Constitution to allow Trump to run for a third term. Ogles believes this initiative is crucial for 'restoring the Republic' and claims that Trump needs more time to reverse the 'decay of the country' caused by the Joe Biden administration. Currently, the US Constitution allows for only two presidential terms.
Original language: es
Publish date: January 28, 2025 06:00 AM
Source:[elpais.cr](https://www.elpais.cr/2025/01/28/trump-no-esta-100-seguro-de-no-poder-postularse-en-las-elecciones-de-2028/)

**Trump Considers Running for Third Term in 2028, Joking About It in Speech to Republican Colleagues**
US President Donald Trump has once again considered running for a third term in 2028, which is not allowed by the US Constitution. In a speech to his Republican colleagues in the House of Representatives, Trump joked about running again, saying, 'I've raised a lot of money for the next presidential campaign, which I probably won't be able to use for myself, but I'm not sure. I think I won't be able to run again.' Trump has made similar comments before, but this time comes after a congressman, Andy Ogles, proposed a constitutional amendment to allow the current president to run again. Ogles argued that Trump 'has shown to be the only figure in modern history capable of reversing the decline of our nation and restoring the greatness of the United States, and he should be given the time he needs to achieve that goal.' Trump also defended his first week in office, taking 'over 350 executive actions' and criticizing his predecessor, Joe Biden, saying that his administration was 'a disaster' and that he was 'extremely incompetent.'

Publish date: January 28, 2025 05:02 AM
Source:[teleprensa.com](https://www.teleprensa.com/articulo/internacional/trump-bromea-republicanos-congreso-presentarse-tercer-mandato-2028/202501280502232016607.html)

**Trump's Potential Third Term: A Proposed Constitutional Amendment**
US Representative Andy Ogles proposed a constitutional amendment on January 23 to allow President Donald Trump to run for a third term. According to Fox News, Ogles suggested revising the current restrictions on presidential terms to enable Trump to serve three terms. Ogles stated, 'This amendment will allow President Trump to serve three terms and ensure that we can maintain the bold leadership our nation so desperately needs.' Ogles believes Trump is the only one who can 'save the nation,' and therefore, he needs an additional four years in office. This proposal comes after Trump's previous statements, where he initially ruled out a third term in 2023, but later expressed openness to running for a third term in November 2024 if the American people wanted him to.
Original language: ru
Publish date: January 24, 2025 07:29 AM
Source:[regnum.ru](https://regnum.ru/news/3943263)

**‘He wants his revenge now’: Trump 2028 is shut down by the internet**
The idea of Donald Trump running for president for a third time in 2028 has gone viral on social media, with MAGA ally Steve Bannon suggesting it could be possible. However, many believe Trump wouldn't be running again, with one user speculating that he only wants to run to avoid jail time. Trump was found guilty of 34 counts of felony in 2024 and sentenced in 2025, but did not serve time in prison. Another user pointed out that the 22nd Amendment of the U.S. Constitution prohibits a person from being elected more than twice to the office of the President, making a third Trump term 'wishful thinking'. Some users even joked about running Barack Obama for president in 2028, suggesting that Trump would be 82 years old by then, while Obama would be 67.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 13, 2025 08:42 AM
Source:[themarysue.com](https://www.themarysue.com/he-wants-his-revenge-now-trump-2028-is-shut-down-by-the-internet/)

**Steve Bannon: Trump Could Run for Third Term in 2028**
Former White House strategist Steve Bannon has expressed that he believes Donald Trump could run for a third term in 2028, despite the 22nd Amendment to the US Constitution, which limits a president to two terms. Bannon argues that Trump's first term ended with Joe Biden's inauguration, making his second term a non-consecutive term. However, other experts say that the amendment is generally understood to prohibit anyone from serving more than two terms as president, regardless of whether the terms are consecutive or not. Bannon said, 'Donald John Trump will place his hand on the King James Bible and take the oath of office, his third victory and second term.' Trump himself has expressed opposition to repealing the 22nd Amendment, saying, 'I would not be for a challenge. Not for me. I would not be for it.' 
Original language: de
Publish date: December 17, 2024 10:20 AM
Source:[az-online.de](https://www.az-online.de/politik/us-wahl-2028-donald-trump-dritte-amtszeit-bannon-verfassung-republikaner-senat-zr-93473078.html)

**Bannon pushes for Trump 2028 at black-tie gala**
At a black-tie gala in Manhattan, Steve Bannon, former chief strategist for President-elect Donald Trump, suggested the possibility of a third presidential run in 2028. Bannon claimed that a loophole in the Constitution would allow Trump to run for a third term, but Mike Davis, a Trump ally, later denied this suggestion. The event celebrated Trump's presidential win, particularly his gains in New York City, where he garnered 30% of the votes cast. Attendees, including Nigel Farage and Corey Lewandowski, praised Trump's choices for key agencies in the new administration. Trump's first campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, warned that 'any individual who exceeded their authority under the Biden administration will be held accountable in the Trump administration.' Trump's longtime aide, Dan Scavino, thanked attendees for their support and said that they are the reason he's going back to the White House with Trump in 35 days. Trump himself thanked attendees and suggested that in four years, Republicans will have another shot, but also indicated that he knows the party will have to move on in 2028.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 17, 2024 10:00 AM
Source:[arkansasonline.com](https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/dec/17/bannon-pushes-for-trump-2028-at-black-tie-gala/)

**Bannon Suggests Trump Can Run for Third Term in 2028**
Former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon suggested that President-elect Donald Trump could run for a third term in 2028, citing the possibility of a non-consecutive term. Bannon made the assertion in a speech to the New York Young Republican Club, saying 'Donald John Trump is going to raise his hand on the King James Bible and take the oath of office, his third victory and his second term.' However, Republican lawyer Mike Davis, who was also at the gala, later clarified that Bannon was 'trolling' and that the 22nd Amendment precludes a third term under any circumstances. Davis stated, 'Steve Bannon is obviously trolling. Only [former President Barack] Obama gets a third term, with his puppet [President Joe] Biden.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: December 17, 2024 02:06 AM
Source:[NewsMax](https://www.newsmax.com/politics/steve-bannon-donald-trump-third-term/2024/12/16/id/1191883/)

**Steve Bannon suggests Trump run for 3rd term in 2028 to explosive cheers (video)**
Steve Bannon suggested that Donald Trump run for a third term in 2028, sparking explosive cheers from his audience. Bannon stated, 'Donald John Trump is going to raise his hand on the King James Bible and take the oath of office, his third victory and his second term.' He also joked that since the Constitution doesn't specify consecutive terms, it's possible for Trump to run again in 2028. This comes after Trump himself 'joked' about a third term, suggesting that FDR's four terms could be a precedent. Trump reportedly joked with House Republicans in November that he would not run again in 2028 'unless you do something.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: December 16, 2024 09:22 PM
Source:[upstract.com](https://boingboing.net/2024/12/16/steve-bannon-suggests-trump-run-for-3rd-term-in-2028-to-explosive-cheers-video.html?ref=upstract.com)

**Donald Trump can run for a third term in 2028, Steve Bannon suggests**
Steve Bannon, a top ally of Donald Trump, suggested that Trump could run for a third term in 2028. Bannon referenced the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution, which states that a person cannot be elected president more than twice, but noted that it does not specify whether this applies to consecutive terms. Trump's transition team and other officials have been contacted for comment, but Trump himself has previously stated that he would not seek to repeal the 22nd Amendment and would serve only four years if re-elected. However, Trump has also made comments that could be interpreted as leaving the door open for a third term, including jokingly suggesting that he might run again in 2028 'unless you do something.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: December 16, 2024 10:30 AM
Source:[Newsweek](https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-third-term-2028-steve-bannon-constitution-2001185)

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, U.S. Presidents or former Presidents do not often declare intentions to run for a third term due to the 22nd Amendment limiting election to the presidency to two terms in office. Since the amendment's ratification in 1951, no president has openly sought a third term due to these constitutional restrictions. In the absence of any substantial legal change or significant historical precedent, the base rate for this type of political statement is very low.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Trump's Behavior and Rhetoric
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Donald Trump is known for making bold and unprecedented statements that garner media attention. His rhetoric has frequently challenged political norms, which might include expressing a desire to run for a third term regardless of constitutional restrictions. This personality trait increases the likelihood of him making such a statement, even if it is not legally feasible.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Loyalty of Trump's Base
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Trump maintains a strong, loyal voter base that values his continued leadership. Expressing a desire to run could energize his supporters and maintain his influence in the Republican party, which may encourage him to make such statements.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Legal and Political Constraints
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Despite Trump's prior unconventional moves, the legal impossibility due to the 22nd Amendment and the lack of any congressional action or serious movement toward changing this law significantly constrains the feasibility of his announcement being serious or credible, acting as a dampening factor.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles confirm that Trump has been openly joking and hinting at the possibility of running for a third term, which aligns with his established behavior of making sensational statements. The pattern of joking while sowing speculative possibilities is consistent with maintaining influence and media presence.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Although Trump has made comments about a third term, the articles also stress that legal constraints remain substantial, with little chance of a constitutional amendment to permit a third term passing. Additionally, expert opinion largely regards such statements as strategic rather than serious intentions.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, U.S. Presidents are limited to two terms in office by the 22nd Amendment. Despite this, former presidents have occasionally expressed interest in continued political involvement or running again under different circumstances, although it is unprecedented after serving two terms. An initial probability can be derived from general statements of political ambition among former high-profile political figures, which can be infrequent. Given the speculative nature of the question, we can consider a base rate of 20% for public figures showing willingness to run again after their term limits, considering it happens but is rare.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Trump's Previous Statements
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Donald Trump has previously shown an inclination to challenge norms and expressed dissatisfaction with election outcomes. His history of provocative statements and actions suggests he might express a desire to run again, even if only to stir public discussion or due to genuine intent.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Legal and Constitutional Constraints
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The 22nd Amendment clearly limits presidents to two terms, making any actual attempt to run again illegal and unprecedented. However, expressing a desire does not equate to a practical campaign and might not be hindered by this factor, but it does reduce the seriousness of such expressions.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Political Environment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Analyzing the current political environment and media focus, there could be factors pushing Trump to remain in the spotlight, especially if he's maintaining influence within the Republican Party or needs to distract from other issues.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Polling and Public Opinion
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Current polling on Trump's favorability and influence within the Republican party shows mixed results. If polling suggests strong support, Trump may publicly express such ambitions to capitalize on this support.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The articles consistently report that Trump has been making jokes and hints about running for a third term, despite constitutional limitations. He has made these comments at various official and public events, reinforcing the prior analysis that his statements are a way to maintain political influence and public attention.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite numerous instances of Trump mentioning a third term, experts and reports indicate there is little serious intention behind these comments. The repeated classification of his remarks as jokes or teases by multiple sources challenges the likelihood of an earnest announcement of intention to run again.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, former U.S. presidents have rarely expressed a desire to run for additional terms after completing their eligibility. However, Donald Trump has demonstrated a non-traditional political approach and has shown interest in maintaining political influence beyond his presidency. Given this, estimating an initial base rate is challenging, but I will set a starting probability at 20% based on the unconventional nature of Trump's political behavior and past instances where he has speculated about continuing influence in U.S. politics beyond his presidency.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Trump's Desire for Influence
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Donald Trump has consistently shown that he values maintaining a strong presence in the political landscape. Expressing a desire to run for a third term could solidify his influence and keep his base energized. This could increase the probability as it aligns with his history of making statements to maintain relevance.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Legal and Constitutional Limits
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The U.S. Constitution prohibits a third term, and Trump is aware of this limitation. Since expressing a desire to run for a third term would highlight this impossibility, it could dissuade such a declaration mainly being framed in terms of influence or symbolic gesture rather than an actual intent.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Messaging Strategy
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Trump may use suggestive language to keep his followers engaged without making direct statements about a third run. This approach allows him to maintain a focused political narrative without contravening constitutional limits directly.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles indicate that Trump's statements about potentially running for a third term are mainly characterized as jokes and strategic moves to maintain influence. Trump's history of making provocative statements aligns with his prior behavior and reinforces the perspective that these comments are not serious declarations of intent.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: While Trump's comments are largely described as jokes, there is notable concern among some Republicans and Democrats who take his statements seriously, potentially increasing the likelihood of him expressing a desire to run. Additionally, external support, like that from Steve Bannon and other allies, suggests there is some base for these ideas within his circle, which could encourage verbalizing such desire.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, the precedent set by the 22nd Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, ratified in 1951, limits the president to two terms in office. Since then, no U.S. president has successfully sought a third term. Presidents have sometimes expressed desires to remain influential or to consider extraordinary circumstances, but they do not campaign for a third term due to this constitutional limitation. Therefore, the historical base rate of past U.S. presidents expressing a desire to run for a third term is very low. Given past behavior, one might estimate the initial probability of such an expression at around 5%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Non-Traditional Behavior
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Donald Trump is known for unconventional approaches and statements regarding his political intentions. This non-traditional behavior might increase the probability that he expresses a controversial desire, even without a genuine legal avenue to pursue a third term.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Legal Constraint Awareness
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Awareness of the legal constraints imposed by the 22nd Amendment typically discourages serious consideration of a third-term run. This would usually deter a public figure from expressing such a desire, though it may not prevent them from making symbolic comments.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Strategy
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Expressing a desire to run for a third term might be used strategically to galvanize a political base or to keep political rivals off balance. In Trump's case, maintaining public interest and media coverage could be strategically beneficial, increasing the likelihood of such a statement.
